post_text:
Copley Engineering Team Takes 2nd Place in the National SourceAmerica Design Challenge

The Copley Engineering Team worked with Weaver ProPak, a non-profit organization, to create a system of devices to assist employees with disabilities in their assembly of brackets and bolts. The B.T.A.S. (Bracket Tightening Assembly System) allows almost every employee at Weaver ProPak to assemble brackets with less fatigue and stress. In addition, the system allows each bracket to be completed seconds faster, ultimately enabling the employees with disabilities at Weaver ProPak to gain employment.

Their invention was entered into the National SourceAmerica Design Challenge in Washington D.C. Although the team was unable to travel to the competition, their invention was judged by a panel of experts and they were awarded a second place finish in the nation. Thank you to Mr. Harder for once again leading this amazing team of young people. #copleypride

National Scholastic Art Awards

Teens in grades 7–12 (ages 13 and up) submit samples in 29 categories of art and writing. In 2019, students submitted nearly 340,000 works of art and writing to the Scholastic Awards.
Submissions are juried by luminaries in the visual and literary arts, some of whom are past award recipients. Panelists look for works that best exemplify originality, technical skill, and the emergence of a personal voice or vision.

Students receiving Gold Keys, Silver Keys, Honorable Mentions, or American Voices & Visions Nominations are celebrated within their communities through local exhibitions and ceremonies. Gold Key works are then judged nationally by an impressive panel of creative–industry experts to receive National Medals, including Gold Medals, Silver Medals, American Voices & Visions Medals, Gold Medal and Silver with Distinction Portfolio Medals, and Special Achievement Awards.

Congratulations Emily Schaffer for being selected in the top 1% of student Artist in the country!

Every once in a while it is important to remember why we do what we do. It is our amazing students. Copley-Fairlawn Middle School is introducing a new program called WEB. WEB stands for: Where Everyone Belongs. The goal of this program is to train 8th grade students to act as mentors for 5th grade students who are making the transition to the middle school.

The students will organize the summer orientation program and then work with 5th grade students throughout the year to assure they are having a great year in a new school. Ms. Cherkala, Mr. Harris and Mrs. Sako are extremely passionate about this and are doing an amazing job preparing.

The picture shows the number of 7th grade students who attended a meeting expressing interest in being a part of this program. Simply AWESOME!!!!!

March 6, 2020

Dear Copley-Fairlawn Families,

Earlier this week the district posted communication regarding COVID-19, also known as Coronavirus. We are continuing to stay in close contact with the Summit County Health Department as well as Akron Children’s Hospital. We are following our infectious disease plan even though at this time, no one in Ohio has been diagnosed with COVID-19. We are regularly disinfecting all schools. We are providing direct instruction to students on handwashing and other appropriate good hygiene techniques, such as using a tissue when you sneeze or cough. We are working hard to decrease anxiety around this very serious concern. In order to assist you at home, we are attaching a parent resource document that provides specific information on how to talk to children regarding COVID-19.

For more information on COVID-19, please visit the following websites:
https://www.cdc.gov/
https://summitcountyhealth.org/

Sincerely,

Brian E. Poe
Superintendent

Compact Carpentry students have been hard at work the last few days helping with a home addition for fellow Compact student Emma Pfouts who has been hospitalized since Oct. after experiencing a severe health crisis. A new addition that will be more conducive to the care Emma will need when she returns home is being built with donated materials and labor. Awesome to watch these exceptional students at work and see them using their gifts talents and abilities to help others in need.
They make us Compact Proud!

An update on the Four Cities Compact's brand new Animal Care and Science Program (@Copley HS).

The Doggie Daycare "Copley Barks" has been a big success! Every day CHS staff members are dropping off dogs which are providing opportunities for the students to learn and interact with a variety of different canines. There are dog baths, simple grooming, exercise and social interaction periods that often lead to some pooped out pooches at the end of the day!

In addition to this the lab continues to grow and develop. New small animals -kitties- chinchillas- rabbit- guinea pigs are there with more to be added.

At the Compact's recent Showcase to sophomore students teacher Rachel McClenaghan and WHS Sr (and CTE Student of the Month) Sami Shaffer talked about the program and gave info to interested students. All in all things are going very well as students interested in Animal Care are having some great experiences!

post_text: Please join me in sending a huge shout out to our Speech and Debate team who collected about 60 pounds worth of pull-tabs to benefit Ronald McDonald House. According to the Ronald McDonald's "Pull-tab Facts" sheet, that 60 pounds equate to 76,020 tabs. Those 76,020 pull tabs equal a little over one mile of tabs. 63,360 tabs equals one mile. At the most recent tournament, there were nine schools, including Copley, that turned in pull tabs. Team members delivered the pull tabs to Ronald McDonald House and we're given a tour of the facility. Way to Go Coach Rote and team.

CHS students enrolled in AP Social Studies courses enjoyed an exciting three-day trip to Washington D.C., chaperoned by Mrs. Chupek, Mrs. Janini, Mrs. Beagle, and Mr. Dies.

Students enjoyed a full and diverse itinerary thanks to extensive planning. On the way to D.C., students visited the Flight 93 Memorial in Shanksville, Pennsylvania.

Once in D.C., students toured the Capitol Building and the Supreme Court, and visited the Smithsonian Institutions on the National Mall including the African American History Museum and the Holocaust Museum. Students also visited Arlington Cemetery and the Korean, Vietnam and WWII War Memorials as well as the Memorials of George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln, Martin Luther King, and Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

A highlight of the trip was the Capitol Building, where students had the opportunity to meet with their Congressman, Anthony Gonzalez, and ask him questions. Students also had the opportunity to sit in the House Gallery and watch Congress in action.
